heading: Chemistry at Jamestown
description: Colonists begin mining, botanical collection, and manufacturing at Jamestown, the first successful English settlement in the Americas.

heading: The Chemical Revolution
description: Lavoisier proves the chemical composition of water using the quantitative method; the phlogistic theory is abandonded in favor of modern methods.

heading: Discovery of Oxygen
description: English chemist Joseph Priestley discovers that air is a mixture of gases, among them the colorless and highly reactive gas we now know as oxygen.

heading: Multiple Effect Evaporator
description: Norbert Rillieux invents the multiple effect evaporator in feat of chemical engineering that revolutionized the sugar processing industry.

heading: First Commercial Oil Refinery
description: Samuel Kier establishes the world's first commercial still for refining crude oil into kerosene and works to develop a clean-burning kerosene lamp.

heading: First Commercial Oil Well
description: Edwin Drake drills the world’s first oil well in Titusville, setting western Pennsylvania as the undisputed center of the early oil industry.

heading: Development of Baking Powder
description: Eben Horsford and the Rumford Chemical Works produce the first true, all-in-one baking powder, making baking easier, quicker and more reliable.

heading: John W. Draper
description: Pioneering photographer and photochemist John W. Draper is elected as the first president of the newly-established American Chemical Society.

heading: Thomas Edison's Menlo Park Lab
description: Edison opens his Menlo Park laboratory where he could build anything from a ladies watch to a locomotive. Here Edison’s phonograph and light bulb were born.

heading: Chandler Lab at Lehigh University
description: The William H. Chandler Chemistry Laboratory opens. Its novel design revolutionizes chemical education and sets a new standard for laboratory construction.

heading: Production of Aluminum
description: Charles Martin Hall produces aluminum by electrochemistry, turning aluminum from a semiprecious metal into the familiar material we know today.

heading: Thomas Edison's West Orange Lab
description: Edison opens his West Orange, N.J., laboratory. The complex is the world’s most advanced and serves as a model for future corporate research labs.

heading: Rachel Lloyd, Pioneer Chemist
description: Lloyd becomes the first American woman to receive a Ph.D. in chemistry. Her work contributes to sugar beet cultivation across the Midwest.

heading: Production of Aluminum
description: The Pittsburgh Reduction Company is formed to employ C. M. Hall’s 1886 invention of producing aluminum by electrochemistry.

heading: Production of Bromine
description: H. H. Dow produces bromine from brine. His business marks a breakthrough for American manufacturers over European competitors.

heading: Production of Calcium Carbide and Acetylene
description: The electric-arc process for producing calcium carbide and acetylene is discovered by accident when Thomas Willson tries to make aluminum.

heading: Atomic Weight of Oxygen
description: E. W. Morley publishes a new value for the atomic weight of oxygen, setting a lasting standard and providing insight into the atomic theory of matter.

heading: George Washington Carver
description: Carver joins the faculty of the Tuskegee Institute, launching a career dedicated to improving the livelihood of Southern farmers.

heading: Columbia Dry Cell Battery
description: The National Carbon Company develops the six-inch, 1.5 volt Columbia battery, the first sealed dry cell battery mass-manufactured.

heading: Development of Occupational Medicine
description: Alice Hamilton comes to Chicago where she identifies occupational diseases plaguing workers in dangerous trades.

heading: Havemeyer Hall
description: Havemeyer Hall at Columbia University is opened for research and teaching under the leadership of renowned chemist Charles Frederick Chandler.

heading: Organic Free Radicals
description: Moses Gomberg of the University of Michigan confirms the existence of an organic free radical, challenging beliefs about the reactivity of carbon.

heading: Biomedical Research at Rockefeller Univ.
description: Rockefeller University is founded as the first U.S. institution devoted to biomedical research and the molecular basis of life.

heading: NIST
description: The federal government’s first physical science research laboratory is founded to develop measurements and standards that strengthen the U.S.

heading: Noyes Laboratory
description: Noyes Laboratory of Chemistry, named for chemistry department leader and noted ACS journal editor William Albert Noyes, opens at the University of Illinois.

heading: Helium in Natural Gas
description: H. Cady and D. McFarland identify helium in a natural gas sample. Before this, helium was thought to be one of the rarest elements on Earth.

heading: Separation of Rare Earth Elements
description: Charles James devises new techniques for separating rare earth elements, producing samples desired by laboratories worldwide.

heading: Bakelite: The World’s First Synthetic Plastic
description: Leo Hendrik Baekeland produces a sample of Bakelite, the world’s first synthetic plastic, ushering in a new era of man-made materials.

heading: Chemical Abstracts Service
description: The first issue of 'Chemical Abstracts' appears. In time, CAS became a vital resource in the work of chemical researchers worldwide.

heading: Mellon Institute
description: The Mellon Institute of Industrial Research is established to provide contract research services to industry and train scientists in fundamental and applied research.

heading: Gilman Hall
description: Built to accommodate expanded teaching and research needs of the College of Chemistry, Gilman Hall at the University of California, Berkeley, is inaugurated.

heading: UOP Riverside Laboratory
description: Universal Oil Products’ Riverside Laboratory is founded to research hydrocarbons and serve the growing oil refining industry.

heading: Modern Analytical Chemistry
description: I. M. Kolthoff, an international leader in the field of analytical chemistry, arrives at the University of Minnesota.

heading: The Raman Effect
description: Indian scientist C. V. Raman makes an important observation about light scattering by liquids, identifying a phenomenon now known as the Raman effect.

heading: Discovery of Penicillin
description: Alexander Fleming discovers penicillin at St. Mary’s Hospital, which leads to the introduction of antibiotics that have greatly reduced deaths from infection.

heading: Smith Memorial Collection
description: Edgar Fahs Smith, a three-time president of the ACS, leaves his world-class history of chemistry library to the University of Pennsylvania.

heading: Wetherill Laboratory
description: Work begins on Purdue University’s Wetherill Laboratory of Chemistry, an important center for chemical education and research in the United States.

heading: Wallace Carothers' Polymers
description: Carothers begins his pioneering studies of giant molecules, discovering the early synthetic materials neoprene and nylon.

heading: Thomas Edison's Botanical Lab
description: Edison joins with Henry Ford and Harvey Firestone to establish the Edison Botanic Research Corporation to investigate a domestic source of rubber.

heading: Scotch Transparent Tape
description: 3M introduces Scotch tape, the first waterproof adhesive tape. It soon becomes a necessity for budget-minded households during the Great Depression.

heading: Savannah Pulp and Paper Lab
description: Charles Herty, an advocate for the growth of U.S. industries, founds a laboratory to develop commercial uses for southern pine trees.

heading: Synthesis of Physostigmine
description: Percy Julian synthesizes physostigmine, making it readily available as a glaucoma treatment. It is the first of Julian’s many achievements in natural products synthesis.

heading: Beckman pH Meter
description: A. O. Beckman markets a pH meter designed to measure the acidity of citrus fruits, an instant success in the new field of electrical instrumentation.

heading: Houdry Process
description: The first full-scale catalytic cracker for producing gasoline from petroleum goes on-stream, improving the octane rating and making today’s efficient gas engines possible.

heading: Discovery of Vitamin C
description: Albert Szent-Györgyi, a Hungarian biochemist, receives the Nobel Prize for his discoveries about the biological importance of vitamin C.

heading: Mexican Steroid Industry
description: Russell Marker begins research on a synthetic method for the production of progesterone, a key hormone used in oral contraceptives.

heading: Development of Penicillin
description: Large-scale production of penicillin is undertaken in the U.S. during WWII through a collaboration of pharmaceutical and governmental scientists.

heading: Selman Waksman and Antibiotics
description: Waksman and his team at Rutgers University begin a search for microbes that fight bacteria, discovering the powerful antibiotic streptomycin.

heading: Production of Nylon
description: DuPont begins commercial production of nylon, the first totally synthetic fiber to be made into consumer products.

heading: Kem-Tone Wall Finish
description: Sherwin-Williams Company introduces the first successful waterborne wall paint and spurs the expansion of 'do it yourself' painting following WWII.

heading: Deep-tank Fermentation
description: In a chemical engineering breakthrough, Pfizer opens the first large-scale penicillin production facility using deep-tank fermentation.

heading: Fluid Bed Reactor
description: The first commercial fluid bed reactor opens at the Baton Rouge, Louisiana, refinery of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

heading: U.S. Synthetic Rubber Program
description: Strategic nationwide research results in the production of the first bale of synthetic rubber, a critical material for the U.S. during World War II.

heading: Polymer Research Institute
description: Herman Mark establishes PRI, the first academic facility in the U.S. devoted to the study and teaching of polymer science.

heading: Tide Detergent
description: Research by scientists at Procter & Gamble lead to the introduction of Tide®, the first heavy-duty synthetic detergent, transforming the chore of laundry.

heading: Production and Distribution of Radioisotopes
description: Oak Ridge National Laboratory delivers the first radioisotope produced for peacetime pursuits like cancer therapy and diagnostics.

heading: Carbohydrate Metabolism
description: Carl and Gerty Cori are awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine or Physiology for demonstrating the cycle of carbohydrates, also known as the Cori cycle.

heading: Frozen Foods
description: Researchers at the USDA begin studying frozen fruits, juices, and other products, developing improvements in the quality and stability of frozen foods.

heading: Polypropylene and HDPE
description: While attempting to convert propylene into gasoline, Phillips Petroleum chemists discover polypropylene and high-density polyethylene.

heading: Hermann Staudinger
description: Staudinger is awarded a Nobel Prize for his work on macromolecules, important to materials science and bioscience.

heading: Acrylic Emulsion Technology
description: Using acrylic technology, Rohm and Hass introduces paints that are easier to prepare and perform better than traditional paints.

heading: Flavor Chemistry Research
description: Keene Dimick builds an early gas chromatograph in the basement of a USDA lab to study the chemical essence of strawberries.

heading: Diagnostic Test Strips
description: The first dip-and-read test for glucose is released, making an inexpensive and immediate means for patients to monitor diabetes.

heading: Radiation Chemistry
description: Cook, Meikle, and Muchmore found Raychem Corporation, applying the new science of radiation chemistry to crosslink polymeric materials.

heading: Food Dehydration Technology
description: Instant potato flakes, developed at the USDA Eastern Regional Research Center, are introduced, making a lasting impact on food processing.

heading: DayGlo Fluorescent Pigments
description: Scientists at Day-Glo Color Corp. receive a patent for producing daylight fluorescent pigments.

heading: Carbon Fibers
description: Roger Bacon demonstrates the first high performance carbon fibers, the strongest and stiffest materials by weight known to man.

heading: Sohio Acrylonitrile Process
description: The first facility using the Sohio process to produce acrylonitrile, a key raw material for synthetic fiber and plastics makers, opens.

heading: NMR Spectrometer
description: Varian Associates introduces the first nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer, an indispensable tool for chemists.

heading: Atmospheric Carbon Dioxide
description: Charles Keeling reports an annual increase in carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere, research that will become a cornerstone of climate science.

heading: Deciphering the Genetic Code
description: Nirenberg and Matthaei at the National Institutes of Health discover the key to breaking the genetic code. Five years later, Nirenberg’s team deciphers DNA.

heading: Nobel Gas Chemistry
description: Neil Bartlett demonstrates the first reaction of a noble gas, previously thought to be inert. Bartlett’s reaction begins the field of noble gas chemistry.

heading: Rachel Carson’s 'Silent Spring'
description: Rachel Carson’s 'Silent Spring' is published. A landmark in modern environmentalism, the book sparked debate about the effect of pesticides.

heading: Camptothecin and Taxol
description: Researchers at the Research Triangle Institute report the discovery of the life-saving anticancer agent Camptothecin.

heading: Cotton Products Research
description: Ruth Benerito and colleagues at the USDA receive a patent for wrinkle-resistant cotton fabrics and challenge synthetic fibers in the market.

heading: MRI Imaging
description: Paul Lauterbur announces the application of NMR for the study of tissues 'in vivo'. His discovery results in the revolutionary medial device MRI.

heading: Tagamet
description: Pioneering work by scientists at Smith Kline & French results in the introduction of cimetidine (commercially known as Tagamet), revolutionizing the treatment peptic ulcers.

heading: Acetyl Chemicals from Coal
description: Eastman Chemical Company becomes the first manufacturer in the U.S. to use coal rather than petroleum as a raw material in acetyl chemicals.

heading: Discovery of Fullerenes
description: Buckminsterfullerene is discovered by researchers at Rice University, opening new fields in organic chemistry and materials science.

heading: Williams-Miles Collection
description: The Williams-Miles History of Chemistry Collection is established at Harding University, documenting chemistry in the U.S. before 1900.
